title: Why is it better for a would-be journalist to be good at several subjects than to be better at just one? - Quora

response.answer_text: I am copy-pasting my response to your other related question, because I had both of your questions in mind when I wrote my answer. In the late nineteenth century the journalist was either a hack or a renaissance man. The ideal was the latter, because all things in life are considered interrelated. I recall Walter Lippman's “pictures in their heads” of the common man which was to be overcome and who were to be protected by the learned man, and so journalism had grown largely out of sociology. But there was also H. L. Menchen who wrote an encyclopedia on the American language while being a witty, biting erudite commentator on business and politics. He obviously cared about the dignity and worth of his readers. Experience with the trials, trivialities, and triumphs of man was also beneficial, whether you rose up out of the popular social scene like Walter Winchel or from the combat zone like Ernest Hemingway. Many times today, though, subject areas are considered so complex it is preferred you have a degree in the field you are reporting in, such as medicine, finance, or aeronautics. But it's not just about the technical. All told, the more rounded - and compassionate — you are the better your reporting will be. You'll have a more mature take on life and be able to view subjects in more than one perspective, and see the interrelationships of the various actors. When we see the plight of the migrants in Lesbos or the fear and exhaustion of medical staff fighting the pandemic how quickly we in the field return to our sociological origin.

response.answer_text: Why is it better for a would-be journalist to be good at several subjects than to be better at just one? I think you will find that to excel at a subject you need to be knowledgeable about many others. If you were to become an expert on the Snail Darter  You would need a working knowledge of geology, climate change, politics, economics, and natural science. Petition Seeks to Remove Snail Darter From Endangered Species List, Marking Conservation Success If you follow politicians, you need to understand the people who elect them. The fun thing is sometimes these ancillary fields of study become the most interesting. Thanks for the A2A. I am sure you will get many interesting responses. If you find something really good write a book. You can always self publish. It is a good way to develop expertise, and get recognized for it.
